title: Glencore Shares Lose Nearly A Third Of Value
text:

Mon, Sep 28, 2015, 19:34 BST - UK Markets closed Glencore Shares Lose Nearly A Third Of Value By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 12 minutes ago View Photo 

Swiss commodity giant Glencore (Xetra: A1JAGV - news ) lost almost a third of its value on Monday, as its shares closed just higher than their lowest ever level. 
They finished down 29% at 69p, slightly up on the all-time low price of 67p recorded earlier in the day. 
The sell-off came after investment bank Investec Securities warned in a report that if there is no recovery in commodity prices in the coming months Glencore’s debt burden will render the company virtually worthless. 
Glencore is around $30bn (£19.8bn) in debt, although the firm did announce a plan earlier this month to cut that amount by a third through the issuance of new shares and the sale of non-core assets. 
Glencore is not alone in struggling; many mining companies face a difficult market environment due to the steep fall in price of commodities such as oil and copper, prompted by the fall in demand which has resulted from China’s economic slowdown. 
But the group, which largely deals in metals including copper and aluminium, has been hit particularly badly, with a year-to-date fall of around 71% overall. 
Glencore declined to comment on the plunge. 
But a person close to Glencore said Investec (LSE: INVP.L - news ) 's analysis was "flawed" and noted the company was on course to have free cash flow - what's left after debt payments - of around $3bn (£2bn) this year at current market prices. 
Anglo American (LSE: AAL.L - news ) , another commodity heavyweight listed on the FTSE 100, also came under fire in the Investec Securities report and lost 10% from its value at the close. 
Overall, the FTSE 100 of leading UK companies saw almost £40bn wiped off its value. 
The index fell by 2.5%, or 150 points, to below the 6,000 mark, to 5,958.9, as figures from China showed profits at its major industrial economies down 8.8%.
